document_title: Wild mouse gut microbiota limits initial tuberculosis infection in BALB/c mice
summary_full: This study investigated the impact of wild mouse gut microbiota on tuberculosis (TB) immunopathology in BALB/c mice. Mice reconstituted with wild mouse gut microbiota (WildR) showed better control of initial TB infection compared to conventional laboratory mice (LabC), with lower bacterial loads in the lungs during the acute phase. While both groups experienced TB-induced gut dysbiosis, the composition of their gut microbiomes differed significantly prior to and during infection. The wild mouse gut microbiota did not alter the typical lung histopathology of TB in BALB/c mice. Although WildR mice exhibited a less pronounced T cell response in the lungs during acute infection, this difference faded over time. Cytokine profiles in infected organs were largely independent of the gut microbiota. In conclusion, the wild mouse gut microbiota offers some early control of TB infection in BALB/c mice, but this advantage diminishes as the infection progresses to the chronic phase.
key_findings: Wild mouse gut microbiota (WildR) conferred better initial control of tuberculosis infection in BALB/c mice, evidenced by lower lung bacterial loads at early time points.
Gut microbiome composition differed significantly between WildR and conventional (LabC) BALB/c mice, with distinct phyla and genera enriched in each group.
Tuberculosis infection induced gut dysbiosis in both WildR and LabC mice, characterized by reduced microbial richness during chronic infection.
The wild mouse gut microbiota did not alter the characteristic lung histopathology of TB in BALB/c mice.
WildR mice showed a less pronounced T cell response in the lungs during acute TB infection compared to LabC mice, which correlated with lower pathogen load.
Cytokine and chemokine profiles in the lungs and spleen during TB infection were largely independent of the gut microbiota composition.
future_research_fields: Elucidating the specific mechanisms by which the wild mouse gut microbiota influences early innate immune responses to TB.
Investigating the long-term effects of the wild mouse gut microbiota on TB progression and host fitness.
Exploring the role of specific microbial taxa enriched in the wild mouse gut microbiota in modulating immune responses.
Determining if the observed early control of TB by wild mouse gut microbiota can be translated to other mouse strains or TB models.
Further research into the gut-lung axis interactions in the context of TB and the influence of microbial communities.

conclusions: The wild mouse gut microbiota provides a degree of early control over initial tuberculosis infection in BALB/c mice, likely through enhanced innate immune responses, but this protective effect diminishes as the infection progresses to a chronic state. The gut microbiota composition differs significantly between conventional and wild-type reconstituted mice, and TB infection induces dysbiosis in both. However, the wild mouse gut microbiota does not alter the typical lung pathology or systemic cytokine profiles associated with TB in this model.
impact_statement: This study suggests that the gut microbiome composition can influence the early stages of tuberculosis infection, highlighting potential avenues for microbiome-based interventions to improve host resistance.
